title: Can a warrant be placed for my arrest for a bill that's not mine?
question: an attorney for a bill collection called me said a warrant was being issued for my arrest if I didn't pay a 600.00 bill on a credit card,i asked him what year is this bill from?he said between 2003 and 2009.i told him there is no way possible that's my bill I was incarcerated from 1999 to 2009.I ask him what card it was and his name and that I am going to seek legal counciling regarding this matter,he said very well I will have the warrant for your arrest issued im through talking to you and hung up. Can a warrant be placed for my arrest for a bill that's not mine?
answers: Ignore them. This is just another heavy handed tactic by the attorney who thinks that you're ignorant of the law. Unless they can show that you committed a fraud when the charge was incurred, there is no way any prosecutor is going to file an arrest warrant just for an unpaid credit card debt.. I would call the state bar and file a complaint because I believe that his tactics in threatening you with an arrest when that is not likely or possible is unethical. NExt time he calls, get his state bar number and tell him you are going to file a complaint with the state bar against him.

We do not have debtor's prison. A warrant could be issued by a Court if you had a judgment against you, your were personally serviced to appear at a judgment debtor's examination and you failed to appear at the examination. None of these circumstances are present in your questions. Therefore, as the others said, this is a scam.
This is a scam. Give them no information and do not pick up their calls.

Under the rule of Ghengis Khan, a person could request to be declared bankrupt and absolved of their debts 3 times. The first time, they would cut off your left hand. The second time, your right hand would be cut off. The third time, your head would be chopped off. Later during medival times, one who was bankruptcy could be jailed, possibly tortured, and enslaved for not paying their debts. The origin of modern bankruptcy law started when one could receive a discharge of their debts after all of their property was taken for the benefit of creditors except for a change of clothes and enough money for a week's worth of room and board....

Today, there are major protections for debts both under state law and through federal bankruptcy law. That being said, someone is feeding you a line. You will not be jailed for not paying a debt, but your assets and income could be at risk.

No one can be arrested for not paying a debt. A warrant for arrest cannot be issued by an attorney for a creditor. Only the police or the District Attorney can request that a judge issue a warrant. And the police and/or prosecutor will not ask you to pay money to settle the matter. If you pay money to a police officer or to a District Attorney in an attempt to avoid arrest, you are guilty of the crime of bribery.
This person is lying to you. Even you do own the debt, you cannot be arrested or put in jail for it.

This is a scam. The caller was not an attorney, and creditors cannot arrest anyone.

If these people can be found, they will be liable for penalties. Sadly, they know this, and are probably not findable.
